text: he was rugby union's first global
superstar just as the sport itself was
turning fully professional and highly
athletic Jonah Lomu had only been capped
twice by the All Blacks before he
arrived in South Africa for the 1995
Rugby World Cup he ended the competition
its biggest name an irresistible mix of
size and speed more than any other game
it was the semi-final against England
which set him apart in his first of four
tries he simply ran over and threw the
England fullback Mike cat four years
later he would score perhaps an even
more extraordinary try against France in
the World Cup semi-final eight men tried
together to bring him down and failed
more remarkable still was that as early
as 1995 Lomu had been diagnosed with a
serious kidney disorder the news was
kept quiet for as long as possible but
eventually in 2004 Lomu had to have a
kidney transplant before I used to
really really struggle in games a lot of
people didn't see their part because
they never knew about but now with the
transplant that I've had in terms of
training I don't struggle at trainings
anymore as much as I used to play we
carried on training and playing rugby in
the lower leagues he had a successful
flirtation with bodybuilding and he said
he wanted to take up boxing as the Rugby
World Cup opened in New Zealand lamode
took a starring role but shortly
afterwards his transplanted organ began
to fail and he was rushed to hospital
you'll be remembered not just as an
unstoppable force on the field but as a
man who helped transform the game Tim
Frank's BBC news
